Name: Cracking the AP Physics 1 Exam, 2015 Edition (College Test Preparation)

ReviewList.Text: Very little effort seems to have gone into making this book.  As an AP Physics 1 teacher, I bought a copy to help generate questions for my own class, particularly in new sections like rotational dynamics.  The rotation section does not say a word about rotational kinetic energy, nor does it talk about angular momentum, both of which are on the new exam.  There are also no questions in the section review related to the new material.  I mistakenly recommended this book to my students based on the AP Physics B book, but will be retracting that recommendation tomorrow in class.  Very frustrating!

I go the book yesterday and paged through it. The questions do not seem to meet the new standards. The practice exams in the book do not seem to be anything like what the AP board has said will be on the test. The "Table of Information" on the included practice exams is nothing like the table that the College Board has published. For the multiple choice parts of the test the instructions say "Calculators may not be used in this part". but calculators WILL be allowed on the AP Physics 1 exam. The questions contain way too many computational questions and not many of the conceptual questions that the College Board has promised will be on the AP Physics 1 exam. I didn't give it a 1 because I think the concepts will be helpful but I wouldn't count on getting a 5 because of what the techniques in the book.

This book is literally the worst for the Physics 1 Exam. As a student, my teacher assigned homework in this book. Many of the questions has material that was specifically mentioned to not be on the exam. Some of the topics formulas when it said it would only be covered conceptually. Princeton review seemed to only change a few things from the Physics B book. Not reccomened to help study for exam.

This book has lots of miss information.  The about the test it tells you that you can't use a calculator on the multiple choice which is a lie and that you can't use the equation sheet on the multiple choice.  Both of these statements are incorrect for the AP physics 1 exam.  This book is very misleading and should be ignored.

I have always maintained that the Princeton Review is the laziest organization on earth.  They have been publishing these reviews forever with no changes.  Mistakes are continued every edition..every year.  This book is just AP Physics B lazily edited.
Good source of material and questions.  However, I do not think it is very well aligned with the actual AP Physics 1 test.
This book demonstrates collegeboard's new emphasis on conceptual thinking but still contains material from the old exam.
There are some things that are missing that are new to the AP Physics 1 course. Other than that is okay.

Time will tell (in May 2015 when the A.P. Physics 1 exam is administered for the very first time) how well the practice questions and sample tests reflect actual exam content...but so far, so good.  Well organized, clear explanations, relevant examples, doesn't jump too abruptly into tricky/abstract practice exercises (as some other books I've purchased seem to do) without giving you one or two basic, "do-able" exercises.  The full-length practice tests (two of them!) look good as well.  I would definitely purchase this one again.

To be fair, this book helped me a lot with the curriculum in school. However, the practice exams in the book are very very very different from what was actually on the AP exam... Though it's not a good exam prep book, its explanation and contents are super easy to understand.

Belie ve they just switched covers with the AP Physic B book. Said that you could not use a caculator for multi choice (and you can). DO NOT recommend this book as has not been revised to match the test. Information is good, but did not know the structure of the test.

I would not recommend this book to anyone! I bought it primarily for the practice tests. There are no experimental set-up questions in the free response and many questions are worded confusingly, some are just simply wrong.
basically the old AP Physics B prepbook without the additional stuff, questions aren't up to Collegeboard standards and the book doesn't help much. I hear Barron's is better
This helps a lot to prepare for the AP Exan. Don't expect to be able to do the whole thing on one night though.
The product came late and my son was unable to use it for his AP Physics test.
Book covered all topics

A great resource but the first couple of sections on kinematics are very boring and In my opinion unnecessary; also I'm wondering whether or not a lesson in physical pendulums should have been included  Everything else is great though.
I find the book very useful and it is very concise, covers the subject well and is easy to understand. It helps me with regular tests too.
Got this book for my son. The practice tests are very useful since there are no full practice tests available for thisexam this year.
Good resource for the new AP Physics course
Great study tool!
I've learned more from this book than what I've learned in class.
my son found this book very helpful and easy to follow

Interesting that this is the first year they have made an AP Physics exam, and we got the book (required) exactly when it came out. I can't really judge the quality until we take the test, but it appears to be exactly what is needed.
Good
